newsitem.title: CHINA: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Debt wallows in currency mire.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Debt wallows in currency mire.

text.p: Asian debt markets wallowed in the mire on Thursday as continued currency volatility sidelined all but the most intrepid of debt issuers.
Even AAA-rated Singapore found its currency sliding to 32-month lows against the U.S. dollar, plunging to levels not seen since November 1994.
"The currency market is very volatile," said one banker, asked why new issues were so scarce.
In Hong Kong, the Hong Kong dollar strengthened, and the swap market steadied, but fluctuating interest rates ruled out the thought of new issues.
Bankers were focusing on the default by Thai property firm Somprasong Land on a euroconvertible bond, and its implications for holders of Asian bonds.
Somprasong missed a US$3.1 million interest payment on a US$80 million euro-convertible bond in February, and bondholders have rejected a settlement offer, opting to call a default.
"Being the first default by a Thai company on an international security, it will be monitored very carefully, and it certainly doesn't do any good for sentiment," said one banker based in Hong Kong.
Thailand's Alphatec Electronics Plc eurobond-holders are to meet in Zurich in early August after Alphatec failed to meet a July 7 payment deadline.
The Alphatec bondholders exercised a put option on US$43.68 million of the firm's total US$45 million euroconvertible.
The decision by Bankers Trust, the bond's trustee, means Alphatec does not have to make a payment until bondholders have met and decided what to do.
Bankers said the market was eager to see a satisfactory agreement between a defaulter and bondholders.
"If it is a reasonable settlement, it may help them to regain investor confidence," a banker in Hong Kong said.
The Asian currency volatility is not deterring Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, which is launching a US$1 billion global bond which bankers said could be increased to US$2 billion.
They said Hutchison's A3/A-plus rating and high rate of return compared to similarly-rated corporates should guarantee an enthusiastic response from investors.
"An A3/A-plus rated company paying 85 basis points to 90 basis points for a 10-year (over U.S. treasuries) is cheap," one banker close to the deal said.
He said the alternative was taking 70-75 basis points for a U.S. corporate with the same rating.
In other news, Hopewell Holdings Ltd declined to comment on reports it was seeking to raise U.S. dollars to help finance the Bangkok road/rail rapid transit system in Bangkok.
A Chinese commercial bank is seeking approval for a five year floating rate certificate of deposit (FRCD) or floating rate note (FRN) featuring puts and calls, bankers said.
They said Taiwan's Hua Nan Commercial Bank expected to award a mandate for its US$150 million FRN by the end of July.
Development Bank of the Philippines is talking to investors about a possible six year samurai issue, bankers said.
